results.body: OVERLAND PARK, Kan. -- The prosecution of a Planned Parenthood affiliate here, the first such criminal case in the nation, has been treated locally as something of a proxy in the battle over abortion rights. Derided by supporters of the organization as politically motivated, the prosecution was celebrated by opponents as the capstone of
results.title: Abortion Case Loses Ground, But Issue Stays Hot in Kansas

results.body: CIMARRON, Kan. -- The ubiquitous swerving and darting forms making their hopscotch journey across the landscape here in recent days are part of one of the most storied -- and least celebrated -- natural migrations on the Great Plains. Yes, the tumbleweeds are on the move again. Over the coming weeks, more and more of these vagabond bundles of
results.title: Drifting Along, Tumbleweeds Are Piling Up Across Plains

results.body: Adding fuel to the debate over his proposal for higher taxes on the rich, Warren E. Buffett said in a letter to a Kansas congressman that he paid $6.9 million in federal income taxes in 2010. The figure represent 17.4 percent of his $39.8 million in taxable income, a percentage he has repeatedly said is too low compared to what his own staff
results.title: In Response To Lawmaker, Buffett Claims 17.4% Tax Rate

results.body: TOPEKA, Kan. -- The startling vote came up at a City Council meeting here on Tuesday, provoked by a run-of-the-mill budget dispute over services that had spun out of control: decriminalize domestic violence. Three arms of government, all ostensibly representing the same people, have been at an impasse over who should be responsible for -- and pay
results.title: Facing Cuts, a City Repeals Its Domestic Violence Law

results.body: A federal judge on Thursday declined to halt a Kansas law that limits the availability of insurance coverage for abortions. The American Civil Liberties Union had requested a temporary injunction against the law, which was approved by the Legislature this year, while the group fights the law in court. Judge Wesley Brown of Federal District Court
results.title: NATIONAL BRIEFING | PLAINS; Kansas: Judge Refuses to Block Abortion Law

results.body: A lawsuit filed in Kansas this month has opened a new front in the legal war over women's reproductive rights. Since last year, 13 states, including Kansas, have enacted laws banning insurance coverage of abortion in the health insurance exchanges created by the federal health care reform law. Some states have gone even further, aggressively
results.title: EDITORIAL; Targeting Women: State efforts to end insurance coverage for abortions endanger women's health and rights

results.body: In a foolhardy indulgence of partisan ideology, Gov. Sam Brownback of Kansas is returning a $31.5 million federal grant that would have made his state a leader in technology development for the new federal health care law. The Republican governor's unilateral rejection was presented as a matter of his grave concern over federal deficit problems.
results.title: EDITORIAL; Gov. Brownback's Selective Budget Worries

results.body: A federal judge ruled Monday that Planned Parenthood would most likely succeed in overturning a new Kansas law that denies the group access to federal family planning money, saying he believes that the law is unconstitutional and was intended to punish the group for advocating for abortion rights. The judge, J. Thomas Marten, granted Planned
results.title: NATIONAL BRIEFING | PLAINS; Kansas: Ruling for Planned Parenthood

results.body: SALINA, Kan. -- This state, so sparsely populated in parts that five counties have no doctors at all, has struggled for years to encourage young doctors to relocate to rural communities, where health problems are often exacerbated by a lack of even the most basic care. On Friday, a new medical school campus opened here to provide a novel solution
results.title: New Path for Small-Town Doctors Starts in a Kansas Small Town

results.body: In three new rulings, federal judges in different states have acted to block immediate enforcement of measures that restrict abortion rights and women's access to affordable contraception, lifesaving cancer screenings and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases. These rulings are important victories for women's health and reproductive rights.
results.title: EDITORIAL; The Courts Step In: Judges' recent rulings show how extreme antiabortion measures have become
